meta.title: Basic blood cell types: Erythrocytes, leukocytes, and platelets

content:
Introduction

Blood is a specialized connective tissue containing various cell types suspended in plasma, each originating from multipotent hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow.  This article reviews the basic types of blood cells, including red blood cells, white blood cells (composed of granulocytes and agranulocytes), and platelets.  Morphologic characteristics, functional roles, and common pathologic alterations are discussed.  Hematopoiesis and cell lineages are explored in detail in a separate article.

Red blood cells



Red blood cells (RBCs), or erythrocytes, are the most abundant blood cells, accounting for approximately 40%-45% of blood volume (

image 1
).  Their primary functions are to transport oxygen from the lungs to the tissues and to return carbon dioxide to the lungs for exhalation.  Measuring 6-8 µm in diameter, RBCs are uniquely biconcave in shape, increasing the surface area available for efficient gas exchange.  Gas exchange is facilitated by hemoglobin, an iron-containing protein that binds oxygen.  RBCs lack a nucleus and organelles, allowing more space for hemoglobin but limiting them to a 120-day lifespan before they are recycled by the spleen and liver.  Erythropoiesis, the differentiation of RBCs from early progenitor cells, is stimulated primarily by erythropoietin produced by the kidneys.  RBC pathology includes:



  • Anemia:  Reduced RBC count or hemoglobin level decreases oxygen delivery.
  • Polycythemia:  Excessive RBC production increases blood viscosity, predisposing to thrombosis.
  • Sickle cell disease:  Abnormal hemoglobin distorts RBCs into a characteristic sickle shape, leading to vascular occlusion, hemolysis, and tissue damage.
  • Thalassemia:  Decreased hemoglobin alpha- or beta-chain production results in abnormal polymers that cause ineffective erythropoiesis and chronic hemolysis.

Granulocytes



Granulocytes are a category of white blood cell (WBC) (leukocyte) characterized by cytoplasmic granules and a lobed nucleus that rapidly respond to injury or infection as a part of the innate immune response.  They include neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils, each containing specialized, preformed granules loaded with enzymes and inflammatory mediators for rapid defensive responses.  Their production and activation are tightly regulated by specific colony-stimulating factors (eg, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor) and interleukins.

Neutrophils



Neutrophils (10-12 µm) are the most abundant granulocytes (comprising approximately 60% of WBCs) and contain multilobed nuclei (2-5 lobes) (

image 2
).  The nuclear segmentation increases as neutrophils mature, with young neutrophils having band-shaped (less segmented) nuclei.  This segmental nature of the nuclei is the reason that mature neutrophils are sometimes referred to as polymorphonuclear leukocytes.



Neutrophils serve as first responders to bacterial infections, rapidly mobilizing to sites of invasion, where they phagocytize (ie, engulf) pathogens.  Their segmented nucleus allows neutrophils to squeeze through tight spaces in blood vessel walls (diapedesis) to reach infection sites without damaging their DNA (

figure 1
).  This nuclear architecture also positions chromatin toward the cell periphery, maximizing central cytoplasmic space available for phagocytosis.  Their characteristic neutral-staining granules contain powerful destructive enzymes, including myeloperoxidase and lysozyme.



Increased neutrophil counts (neutrophilia) are seen in infection or inflammation.  Decreased neutrophil counts (neutropenia) can occur due to various reasons—including chemotherapy, severe infections, and vitamin B12/folate deficiency—increasing susceptibility to infections.

Eosinophils



Eosinophils (12-17 µm) comprise approximately 2%-4% of WBCs and contain bilobed nuclei, resembling a pair of connected lobes (

image 3
).  This bilobed nuclear structure facilitates cellular mobility and flexibility, allowing eosinophils to migrate efficiently into inflamed tissues.  Their prominent eosinophilic (red-orange staining) granules contain cytotoxic molecules (eg, major basic protein, eosinophil peroxidase) optimized for combating parasitic infections by disrupting pathogen cell membranes.  Eosinophils also regulate allergic reactions by modulating inflammatory responses.



Increased eosinophil counts (eosinophilia) suggest an allergic process (eg, asthma, hay fever), parasitic infection (eg, helminths such as Ascaris), drug reaction (eg, DRESS [Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms]), or certain autoimmune disorders (eg, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis).

Basophils



Basophils (12-15 µm), the rarest granulocytes (comprising <1% of WBCs), have bilobed nuclei often obscured by dense, dark purple granules (

image 4
).  These large granules store histamine and heparin, critical mediators of allergic reactions and inflammation.  The basophil's granule-packed cytoplasm enables rapid, controlled release of histamine to induce vasodilation and enhance immune cell access to affected tissues, facilitating a prompt inflammatory response.  Increased basophil counts (basophilia) are rare but can be seen in certain types of malignancy (eg, chronic myeloid leukemia, myeloproliferative disorders).

Agranulocytes



Agranulocytes, another category of WBCs, lack prominent cytoplasmic granules compared to granulocytes and are critical for cell-mediated immunity and antigen recognition.  They consist of lymphocytes and monocytes.

Lymphocytes



Lymphocytes (6-15 µm), constituting an estimated 20%-40% of WBCs, typically feature a large, round nucleus surrounded by a narrow rim of basophilic cytoplasm (

image 5
).  This high nucleus/cytoplasm ratio allows for the storage of a large amount of genetic information essential for generating adaptive immunity processes (eg, antigen recognition, immune memory).  Subtypes include B cells (producing specific antibodies through plasma cell differentiation), T cells (targeting infected or cancerous cells through cytotoxicity or helper functions), and natural killer cells (recognizing and eliminating virus-infected cells via perforin and granzyme release).  Lymphocyte differentiation is driven by antigen exposure and cytokines (eg, IL-2, IL-7) that stimulate maturation into effector or memory cells (with heightened response capabilities on reexposure).



Lymphocytosis can be seen in viral infections and lymphoid malignancies (eg, chronic lymphocytic leukemia).  In contrast, lymphopenia is seen in immunodeficiencies and, occasionally, certain viral infections (eg, HIV, COVID-19).

Monocytes



Monocytes (12-20 µm), comprising approximately 3%-8% of WBCs, contain large, irregularly shaped, kidney-bean nuclei with abundant gray-blue cytoplasm (

image 6
).  Their expansive cytoplasmic volume facilitates phagocytosis of pathogens and debris.  On migration into tissues, monocytes differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells—specialized antigen-presenting cells crucial for coordinating immune responses by processing and presenting antigens to T cells.  The differentiation of monocytes is promoted by macrophage colony-stimulating factor.



Monocytosis can be seen in chronic infections (particularly bacterial infections [eg, tuberculosis]), chronic inflammatory conditions (eg, sarcoidosis), and certain malignancies (eg, chronic myelomonocytic leukemia, acute monocytic leukemia).  In contrast, monocytopenia is less common but may occur in hairy cell leukemia and as an adverse effect of certain medications (eg, chemotherapy agents).

Platelets



Platelets (thrombocytes) are the smallest blood cells (2-4 µm) and are irregularly shaped fragments derived from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow (

image 7
).  Their differentiation is regulated primarily by thrombopoietin produced by the liver.  The small size of platelets and the lack of nuclei optimize rapid circulation and facilitate quick adhesion to damaged vessel walls, forming initial platelet plugs.  Platelets contain numerous granules filled with clotting factors (eg, fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor) and growth factors (eg, platelet-derived growth factor), enabling prompt secretion on activation to stabilize blood clots and promote tissue healing.  With a 7- to 10-day lifespan, their production and function are tightly regulated to prevent excessive bleeding or clotting.



Thrombocytopenia (low platelets) increases the risk for bleeding.  Thrombocytosis (high platelets) may lead to thrombosis.  Platelet dysfunction (eg, Bernard-Soulier syndrome, Glanzmann thrombasthenia) impairs clotting, even in the setting of normal counts, due to molecular defects in platelet adhesion or aggregation.

Summary



Blood consists of 3 main cell types, each with specialized functions.



Red blood cells (erythrocytes), the most abundant blood cells, are responsible for oxygen transport via hemoglobin.  Common disorders include anemia (low red blood cell count), polycythemia (excess red blood cells), and sickle cell disease (abnormal hemoglobin).



White blood cells (leukocytes) are key to immunity and are divided into granulocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils) and agranulocytes (lymphocytes, monocytes).  Neutrophils fight bacterial infections, eosinophils combat parasites and allergies, and basophils release histamine in allergic responses.  Lymphocytes (B cells, T cells, and natural killer cells) mediate adaptive immunity, whereas monocytes mature into macrophages and dendritic cells, aiding in pathogen clearance.  Abnormal white blood cell counts can indicate infections, inflammation, or malignancies.



Platelets are small cell fragments essential for clotting; imbalances can lead to bleeding disorders (thrombocytopenia) or excessive clotting (thrombocytosis).
